name: Audit
description:
An **Audit** is a structured method for **evaluating compliance, performance, and improvement areas** within systems, operations, or processes. It can be used to verify adherence to internal procedures, regulatory requirements, or industry standards, and to support learning and accountability across the organization.



An **Audit** is based on your business area, process, system or activity and provides a framework for planning, conducting, and documenting audit findings. In this template you can define the audit scope, register audit items, and track deviations or observations. For each audit item, you can describe:



*   Area or topic reviewed

*   Observations or non-conformities

*   References to requirements or standards

*   Recommended actions and responsible persons



With this template, you get a complete audit process — from planning and conducting the audit, to recording findings, assigning corrective actions, and ensuring systematic follow-up and closure.

fields.description:
This field is used to assign the single organizational unit that will be responsible for the record and any related follow-up activities. The unit is selected from a predefined hierarchical list in Dmaze, reflecting your organization’s structure. By default, this hierarchy mirrors your official unit setup, with top-level departments and any sub-units nested underneath.

 

🎯 Purpose

To clearly define which part of the organization owns the record and is accountable for its implementation, monitoring, or resolution. Only one unit can be selected per record to maintain clear accountability.

 

👥 Roles

- Initiator or Owner: Selects the unit based on responsibility and scope.
- Responsible Unit: Oversees required actions, ensures follow-up, and provides reporting.

 

💡 Why this matters

Assigning the correct unit ensures governance clarity, improves reporting accuracy, and aligns follow-up responsibilities with the right part of the organization.

 

🚩 Tips

- You can only select one unit for each record.
- Select the unit with primary responsibility for the record.
- Navigate the hierarchy to choose the most specific applicable unit.
- The available units and hierarchy are managed by your Dmaze administrator.
- Start typing at least two characters in the search box to filter and display all matching units, making it faster to find units in large hierarchies.

 

📌 Examples

- Finance Department
- Operations Division
- Compliance and Risk Management Unit

fields.description:
This field defines the exact date by which the measure must be completed. This value is mandatory and must be set before the measure can enter the implementation workflow. Relative time frames (e.g. 'within 30 days') are not supported – only calendar dates are allowed.

 

🎯 Purpose

To establish a clear and fixed target date for completing the measure.

 

👥 Roles

- Measure Creator or Initiator: Sets the deadline during measure creation.
- Responsible Person: Plans work to meet the defined date.

 

💡 Why this matters

Deadlines help ensure timely action, support progress tracking, and define accountability. They are also required to trigger the next workflow steps.

 

🚩 Tips

- The deadline must be filled in before the measure can be moved to implementation.
- Use a realistic date that reflects the complexity, dependencies, and resource availability.
- Communicate changes to deadlines clearly if adjustments are needed.
- Monitor upcoming deadlines using reports, dashboards, or filters.

 

📌 Examples

- “2025-09-01”
- “2025-12-15”

 

⚠️ Note: Only absolute calendar dates are allowed (format: YYYY-MM-DD). Relative expressions like 'in two weeks' are not supported.
fields.label: Due date

fields.description:
This field captures a detailed explanation of the measure – what it aims to achieve, how it will be implemented, and what outcome is expected. A well-written description ensures clarity for everyone involved and helps support follow-up, evaluation, and accountability.

 

🎯 Purpose

To document the full scope, intent, and expected results of the measure.

 

👥 Roles

- Measure Creator or Owner: Provides a clear and complete description.
- Responsible Person: Uses the description as guidance for implementation.
- Reviewers: Refer to the description when evaluating completion and effectiveness.

 

💡 Why this matters

A clear and specific description reduces misunderstandings and ensures that all parties share the same understanding of what needs to be done.

 

🚩 Tips

- Focus on what will be done, by whom, and to what effect.
- Include relevant procedures, standards, or references where appropriate.
- Avoid vague statements like “Improve process” – be action-oriented and measurable.
- Break large or complex actions into smaller steps or milestones if needed.

 

📌 Examples

- “Conduct cybersecurity training for all staff and document attendance by Q3.”
- “Replace all fluorescent fixtures with LED lighting in building A and B.”
- “Review and update data retention policy to align with regulatory changes.”

 

⚠️ Note: This field can be updated throughout the lifecycle of the measure if details evolve or clarification is needed.
fields.label: Description

fields.description:
This field displays the title of the parent item to which this measure belongs. The link is automatically set based on where the measure was created and cannot be changed. It provides quick access back to the originating item, helping users understand the context in which the measure was established.

 

🎯 Purpose

To show the source item this measure is associated with and allow easy navigation to it.

 

👥 Roles

- All users: Use the link to view the full context and rationale behind the measure.

 

💡 Why this matters

Measures are always created as part of a specific record (e.g., an observation, risk, or incident). This link confirms where the measure originated and enables traceability.

 

🚩 Tips

- Click the link to go directly to the parent record.
- Use the information in the parent to better understand the need for the measure.
- Note that this connection is fixed and cannot be edited.

 

📌 Examples

- “Observation: Missing emergency lighting in corridor”
- “Event #103: Data breach affecting payroll system”

 

⚠️ Note: This field is system-controlled and reflects where the measure was created. It cannot be changed by users.
fields.label: Finding

fields.description:
This field defines the priority level of the measure, indicating how urgent or important it is to act. Use this to help stakeholders and responsible users understand which measures should be addressed first.

 

🎯 Purpose

To classify the urgency of the measure and support prioritised planning and resource allocation.

 

💡 Why this matters

Clear prioritisation helps focus attention on the most critical actions and prevents important measures from being delayed.

 

🚩 Tips

- Use 'High' for time-sensitive or high-risk measures that require immediate attention.
- Use 'Medium' for measures that are important but not urgent.
- Use 'Low' for improvements or actions that can be scheduled later.
- Review priority levels regularly and adjust if necessary.

 

📊 Available options

| Priority | Description                          |
|----------|--------------------------------------|
| High     | Immediate attention required         |
| Medium   | Important, but not time-critical     |
| Low      | Can be addressed when resources allow |

 

⚠️ Note: These values may be customised by your organisation’s administrator.
fields.label: Priority

fields.description:
This field is used to assign the person responsible for implementing the measure. The dropdown menu shows active Dmaze users by their full name (first and last). Assigning a responsible person is required before the measure can be set to implementation.

 

🎯 Purpose

To ensure clear accountability for executing and reporting on the measure.

 

👥 Roles

- Measure Creator or Initiator: Selects the responsible person from the list.
- Responsible User: Accepts or declines the task and updates progress.

 

💡 Why this matters

Assigning responsibility ensures that the measure is actively followed up. It also enables system-generated email notifications, improving communication and accountability.

 

🚩 Tips

- Choose someone with the right skills, role, and authority to carry out the measure.
- A valid email address is required to receive notifications – a warning icon will appear if the selected user is missing this.
- The responsible person will receive an email when the measure is moved to implementation status, asking them to accept or decline the task.

 

📌 Examples

- “Elena Rossi (IT Security Manager)”
- “Jens Madsen (Facilities Team)”

 

⚠️ Note: Only active users registered in Dmaze can be assigned. Email notifications require a valid address on the user profile.
fields.label: Responsible

fields.description:
This field shows the current status of the measure (task or action), reflecting its progress from creation to closure. The status updates automatically based on user decisions and system events, and determines when a measure is considered closed. Email notifications are triggered at key decision points to keep responsible parties informed.

 

🎯 Purpose

To track and manage the lifecycle of a measure, ensure all stakeholders are aligned, and maintain control over implementation, acceptance, and completion.

 

👥 Roles

**Initiator** (e.g. process owner, risk owner, team lead):  
- Creates the measure and chooses between implementing, acknowledging it already exists, or cancelling it.  
- Assigns a responsible person and sets a due date if implementation is selected.  
- Approves, cancels, or rejects the completed measure.

**Measure Responsible**:  
- Accepts, declines, cancels, or closes the measure as “Existing” or “Do not implement”.  
- Updates progress status during implementation.  
- Marks the measure as complete for approval.

 

💡 Why this matters

A well-defined status lifecycle ensures consistent handling of all measures, enables transparency, automates follow-up through email notifications, and defines clear closure criteria. It supports accountability across different roles.

 

🚩 Tips

- Make sure 'Responsible' and 'Due Date' are filled in before starting implementation.  
- Use “Exists” only when the action is already implemented and verifiable.  
- Measures are considered **closed** when status is: **Existing**, **Cancelled**, or **Completed (100%) (approved)**.  
- Emails are automatically sent when a measure is assigned, declined, completed, cancelled, or approved.  
- If a measure is rejected after completion, the responsible person must continue working until it can be approved.

 

📌 Examples

- A user creates a measure and selects “Do not implement”. The status becomes **Cancelled**, and the measure is closed.  
- A responsible user accepts a measure, completes it, and the initiator approves it. The status becomes **Completed (100%) (approved)**, and the process is complete.

💬 **Want to see the actual lifecycle for this measure?**  
Click the **Change log** button in the top-right corner above this field to view the full step-by-step history, including who made each change and when.

 

📊 Status Lifecycle Overview

1. **Measure is created** → `Identified (pending decision)` *(System)*  
2. **Initiator clicks**:
   - *Implement* → Requires Responsible + Due date → `To be implemented (pending accept)` *(email sent to Responsible)*  
   - *Exists* → `Existing` *(Closed)*  
   - *Do not implement* → `Cancelled` *(Closed)*
3. **Responsible user chooses**:
   - *Decline* → `To be implemented (declined)` *(email sent to Initiator)*  
   - *Accept* → `In progress (not started)` → Access to:
     - `In progress (25%)`, `In progress (50%)`, `In progress (75%)`
     - `Completed (100%) (for approval)` *(email sent to Initiator)*  
     - *Cancel* → `In progress (cancelled)` *(email sent to Initiator)*  
   - *Exists* → `Existing` *(Closed)*  
   - *Do not implement* → `Cancelled` *(Closed)*
4. **Initiator chooses**:
   - *Approve* → `Completed (100%) (approved)` *(Closed)*  
   - *Reject* → `Completed (100%) (not approved)` *(measure reopens)*  
   - *Cancel* → `In progress (cancelled)` *(Closed)*

 

✅ When is a measure considered closed?

- `Existing`  
- `Cancelled`  
- `Completed (100%) (approved)`

 

⚠️ Note: The list of selectable status options and transitions may be customised by your organisation’s administrator to reflect internal processes and governance.

If the measure is decided to be implemented, an e-mail will be sent automatically to the person responsible.

Reconsider if the measure should be implemented or not.
